content.description:
“Yesterday I received my first payment for the first quarter of the new [National] Health Service. . . . To say I was profoundly shocked would be an understatement; I was stunned, particularly as a protagonist [supporter] of a free medical service. . . . The people of this country have been provided with better medical care, including Dental, Ophthalmic [eye], and other services, than ever before. They have taken full advantage of this comprehensive scheme, for the Doctors have worked as hard, if not harder, than in their peak winter epidemic periods. In return they have been presented with a mere pittance for their skill and responsibility, in their most exacting and ceaseless occupation.
I believe, Sir, you have stated that the Bill was designed, in part, to relieve the doctor of financial anxiety, but it now appears that his position is to be worse than it ever was. You surely realize that Medicine and Finance are ill-wedded companions.”
Letter sent by a medical doctor in Leeds, England, to Aneurin Bevan, British political official, 1948
content.question: Which of the following best describes the significance of the doctor’s complaints in the letter?

choices.label: They reflect the expanding European economy during the postwar period referred to as the economic miracle.
They anticipate the pressures that social programs would come under as taxes increased and budgets became strained.
They reflect the improvements in medical technology that came about after the Second World War.
They anticipate the political debates over Great Britain’s entry into the European Union.

content.answer: They anticipate the pressures that social programs would come under as taxes increased and budgets became strained.
